Class MagicSquare

  • java.lang.Object
    • MagicSquare

  • public class MagicSquare
extends java.lang.Object
    Program excepts input from the user in standard format. It will run a series of 3 tests on the inputs to check to see if it is not only a perfect square matrix, but if the matrix is a Magic Square as well.
    Version:
    1.0, SER_216, 03-19-2017
    Author:
    Kothrade, Cal

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      MagicSquare()
      Default constructor which sets the size of the matrix to 0.
      MagicSquare(java.lang.String[] string)
      Constructor which converts the passed String array to an Integer array which will represent the perfect square matrix.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int calcSum()
      Calculates the sum of the first column of the matrix and uses this sum as the standard to be achieved in the addition processes for rows, columns and diagonals.
      int[] getMatrix()
      Getter method for the Integer array representation of the matrix.
      static java.lang.String[] initiate()
      Begins the process of requesting inputs from the user by using a standard method of input.
      static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
      The main method for the driver of the program.
      static boolean perfectSquare(java.lang.String[] test)
      Accepts the String array of input values and determines if the number of input values (size of array) is a perfect square, or in other words if it passes the first test.
      void setMatrix(int index, int value)
      Setter method for individual index values of the matrix.
      boolean testColumns()
      Part 2 of the 3rd test.
      boolean testDiagonals()
      Part 3 of the 3rd test.
      boolean testOccurence()
      The 2nd test which ensures that every value from 1 to the number of values entered appear in the matrix, and no more than one time.
      boolean testRows()
      The 1st part of the 3rd test, which calculates the sums of each row in the matrix and determines if they are equal to the benchmark value.
      java.lang.String toString()
      A method which returns a string designed to display the contents of the matrix.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • MagicSquare

        public MagicSquare()
        Default constructor which sets the size of the matrix to 0.

      • MagicSquare

        public MagicSquare(java.lang.String[] string)
        Constructor which converts the passed String array to an Integer array which will represent the perfect square matrix.
        Parameters:
        string. - The String array containing the values.

    • Method Detail

      • setMatrix

        public void setMatrix(int index,
                      int value)
        Setter method for individual index values of the matrix.
        Parameters:
        index. - Index position where the value is to be inserted.
        value. - The value to be inserted into the matrix.

      • getMatrix

        public int[] getMatrix()
        Getter method for the Integer array representation of the matrix.
        Returns:
        matrix. Array representation of the matrix.

      • testOccurence

        public boolean testOccurence()
        The 2nd test which ensures that every value from 1 to the number of values entered appear in the matrix, and no more than one time.
        Returns:
        True if all of the values in the matrix occur only and at least once.

      • calcSum

        public int calcSum()
        Calculates the sum of the first column of the matrix and uses this sum as the standard to be achieved in the addition processes for rows, columns and diagonals. (Benchmark Value).
        Returns:
        sum. The sum of the first column.

      • testRows

        public boolean testRows()
        The 1st part of the 3rd test, which calculates the sums of each row in the matrix and determines if they are equal to the benchmark value.
        Returns:
        True if all of the rows in the matrix are equal to the benchmark value.

      • testColumns

        public boolean testColumns()
        Part 2 of the 3rd test. Calculates the sums of the Columns in the matrix and determines if they are all equal to the benchmark value.
        Returns:
        True if all columns in the matrix are equal to the benchmark value.

      • testDiagonals

        public boolean testDiagonals()
        Part 3 of the 3rd test. Calculates the sum of the Diagonal paths and determines if they are equal to the benchmark.
        Returns:
        True if both Diagonal paths are equal to the benchmark.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        A method which returns a string designed to display the contents of the matrix.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        disp. A string containing the contents of the matrix.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        The main method for the driver of the program. Calls all of the functions and methods to determine if a matrix is a Magic Square.
        Parameters:
        args -

      • initiate

        public static java.lang.String[] initiate()
        Begins the process of requesting inputs from the user by using a standard method of input.
        Returns:
        string1. String array containing entered input values.

      • perfectSquare

        public static boolean perfectSquare(java.lang.String[] test)
        Accepts the String array of input values and determines if the number of input values (size of array) is a perfect square, or in other words if it passes the first test.
        Parameters:
        test. - The String array of input values.
        Returns:
        True if the number of input values is a perfect square.
